text: All right everyone thanks for making the time for this session today I know that there's other interesting sessions as well happening at the same time I'm happy to be here with all of you today My name is Cristian I work at AWS I am a specialist compute SA and basically what I have is that I help customers try to make an efficient use of their compute workloads That of course as you can imagine most of my conversations with customers are around kubernetes So today I'm going to cover a few topics around that and some topics that I'm quite passionate about Performance autoscaling and kubernetes And before I get started with a lot of the things that I would like to unpack today here in 30 minutes it's going to be but hopefully I can make it and show you not just what is this like a mental model but I want you to have a takeaway of a few key points a few practices that you can actually put in practice if you're using KEDA Carpenter specifically I will assume that you might have heard about KEDA Carpenter I'm not going to cover the basics We had a few sessions yesterday that covered that so hopefully you made it Now let's start with the fundamental problem when we start talking about performance The reality is that we have nowadays distributed systems that are complex We just watched a session before me that was talking about open telemetry and how you can actually instrument your application how important it is to instrument your application as well as Whitney was saying in the beginning And the other topic that is interesting here is there are too many tools around performance analysis Every developer every platform engineer nowadays has a preference of these tools Along with that in addition to that one of the things that people used to think about auto scaling and performance is you're not going to get it's basically CPU utilization If you look at Brendan Gregg he's basically an engineer of performance He used to be a performance engineer at Netflix And he talks a lot about this and saying CPU utilization is not a good metric It's basically a saturation metric And if you start getting into that with auto scaling usually you start with CPU utilization And don't get me wrong at least do something with auto scaling right But that might not be the end goal And what I would like to basically add here CPU utilization alone is wrong So maybe we can think about is there any good metric Or is there basically a combination of metrics So sometimes your application might be saying like CPU utilization is great memory utilization is great But your users might be telling you that it's not working I've been in projects many times where actually all the dashboards were green or metrics or logs were green But the reality was that we had a lot of errors latency was going up So what I'd like to share with you is basically some mental model I'm going to start with that Then I'm going to go specifically into these tools that I mentioned before This performance analysis I'm going to take the approach that Annapurna Labs have been implementing around these years If you don't know Annapurna Labs is basically the startup that we acquired a few years ago And when we started to create chips or our own custom chips If you didn't know basically we started with creating a lot of them One of the first projects that we did on the compute angle was to basically put into the hardware the virtualization Then we started with networking chips and then we started with CPU chips That's basically when it came to Graviton And that team basically runs a mental model of doing this performance analysis Every time that they deploy or create a new chip you can imagine that at the scale that they will need to make sure that the chip is going to be providing the performance that our customers need So lucky for us they basically deploy a tool and a mental model that is basically applying all of these practices If you have time later today or in the future I'll recommend you to give it a look to this performance runbook that this team is actually running every time that they release something into these applications Basically I'm going to cover that tool and how it relates to a Kubernetes ecosystem because it's basically the context in what we are today What I really like to think about this is that we changed the mindset about well the application is not working The performance that our customers are telling us it's basically been degraded So instead of going like saying of course we're going to go and get the logs and telemetry but if we're going to go and test and try to make that the performance of the new application is going to be delivering what we have maybe we will need to start asking the right questions So look at this basically It says how does my Java applications throughput on our compute nodes compared to current x86 nodes in my Kubernetes cluster at p99 latency of 10 milliseconds handling 60  get and 40  put operations It's a very concrete it's a very extensive question but look at what we're doing here We already know that it's a Java application We already know that we are going to be measuring throughput and we are going to be comparing two architectures two different architectures but it's not just only that We're going to basically say hey what about the p99 latency that it needs to be the SLA needs to be on the 10 milliseconds and this is basically what I'm going to be doing or what I will expect my application to do So that's basically a better question than just saying like yes I'm going to go and send my application and let's see if it performs better It depends right So to answer that question and to help you on making that analysis let me start giving you a few tools Now I'm going to switch into giving you a few recommendations practical recommendations on what you can start applying The first thing is that the mental model that I was mentioning before it's basically if you go around it it's very verbose but with a reason But you can summarize it in three basically steps Define your benchmark which is basically something similar to what we did before and then you have to make sure that you configure your load generator in this case if it's a web app for example and the system under test or SUT which correlates to what I was saying before Then do analysis performance And for this we have this tool that I was mentioning before that the Anakurna Labs team is using which is called Aperf This is a tool that I mentioned at the beginning that we have a lot of tools when we're doing CPU profiling and application profiling as well So the aim of this tool is basically to provide you a visibility one single pane where you can look at these different metrics and you can actually compare So what I'm going to show you later on is how you can actually compare this exactly question that I was asking before how to compare ARM and x86 and what things I can start looking at So perhaps the very interesting part that I've seen that is becoming more common and common is the CPU flame graphs So this is basically a project that again the same author that I mentioned a while ago and it's been popular nowadays and we can offer that in Aperf too And the idea is that you know that when you are running tests too many things are going to be happening And if you correlate in timeline the name of the functions the time that has been taken it's going to take a long So what he did is basically created this tool and aggregated and you can see in the x86 the functions and it's not related to time It's just basically how much CPU utilization these functions took while you were analyzing And on the y axis it's basically the function that is consuming more CPU So you can start over at the top saying like hey this is basically and the colors are getting you on to something like that right So we can start talking about this and going deeper So I would recommend you if you go and check this link you're going to have more and more detailed explanation of what flame graphs are So what I want to show you here is basically on my first demo that I have here today You can see here that the project is open source You can run it everywhere You could say that it's cloud and even you can run it on prem Of course this is started as a tool that you will be not for a container environment but we've been working on making it container friendly because we receive a lot of customers that are asking us for how to profile this type of application on guess what on Kubernetes So what I'm going to show you here I have a lot of terminals here but I'm going to guide you on to the things that I want to show you And first I want to explain what I have all this kind of mess that I have here Here you can see here that I have two obligations and one's going to be running on ARM and x86 I have one path because what I would like to do is to compare apples to apples And I don't want to even though I really care about auto scaling I don't want to put into the mix more noise or I just want to make sure that if I run the same test it will be as similar as possible to the other test because I want to compare how they behave And you can see what I'm going to be showing you here the CPU utilization because typically what we see customers and you're not going to let me lie on this but typically customers are auto scaling on CPU utilization when they see 60 70  of GCP utilization And my purpose today is to show you that actually it's fine if you go above that number It's fine if you actually make an efficient use Of course it's going to depend on your application I'm not saying that you should look for having CPU 100 CPU utilization Maybe that's not going to work in your environment but when we are doing this type of test it's actually useful to do that So what I'm going to do here is basically use K6 and this is going to start running a test And what is going to happen right now is that a lot of pods are going to be on pending state Carpenter is going to start to launch the node that it needs to run this test Because remember what I wanted to do is basically of course not run the load in the same node Even though it's going to be in the same cluster which we can argue that maybe that's not isolated at all But for the purpose of the demo and if you want to get started it's a good starting point So what I'm going to do here is basically as soon as the nodes are going to be running I can see the logs of the application here And of course this test is going to take three minutes five minutes to finish And I don't want us to keep waiting on here What I'm going to do basically I'm just going to show you that this is running live And I did a similar test and I want to show you the results of what the tool is going to So what I'm going to do here this is basically the logs of the application of the load test And what I'm going to do here is to run Aperf And you can see here that we're doing something like kubectl Aperf with a few parameters here And we basically send the name of the node that we want to analyze and Aperf options the report name And what this is going to do look at this it's going to basically deploy that Aperf path into the node And it's going to start to do the performance analysis of what is happening while I'm doing the test And of course that is going to be running for 90 seconds but I have a shorter demo that is going to run for 15 seconds simply because what I want to show you is that it's going to be doing and I can basically go over here it's going to start looking at the nodes that it needs to analyze then it's going to deploy the path And it noticed that it's an instance type like this And it's going to say like hey what are the bots that are running in this node so that I can start analyzing them and actually tie the pods with a process ID because at the end it's going to be a process ID running in the host right So remember Aperf is going to be taking the analysis or that telemetry or that information that it's emitting and it's going to start to collect the data And you can see here that it's basically working it's going to run for 15 seconds I know it's not too much And when it's done it's going to create a report and it's going to generate it's going to download it from the Kubernetes cluster to my local machine it's going to untar it and then automatically it's going to open a new browser with analysis This might take a while and I'm going to take advantage of what I have here I generated here when by the way when that tool finishes it's going to open automatically here so I might get interrupted into that So what I did is basically before I run the test for five minutes because it's something meaningful even five minutes might not be enough but you can run it for longer And when you compare the two tests that you did I'm calling it x86 arm but it could be b1 b2 you can see here how Aperf is generating the report There it is here's the live report that it created So I'm going to stick with this because it's more meaningful and you can see the comparison I can go here with CPU utilization and I can compare side by side how they are comparing with different perspectives of CPU utilization So remember that it's not only about CPU utilization load average or one five 15 minutes it's beyond that You can see here of course the flame graphs and you can compare them and you can see basically the results of you can analyze here well the other analysis finished and you can compare that you can actually reverse and sometimes it depends on your workload when you reverse that flame graph you can actually see very interesting stuff All right so that's it that's basically what I wanted to show you with performance analysis in Aperf Let me start talking about what about autoscaling because one of the premises is that how what we've done before influenced that autoscaling part because at the end of the day we want to make sure that it's not only running as we expect it to run but how do we make sure that when we scale out and when we add more pods or more replicas we are doing it in the most efficient way But before going that when we're talking about autoscaling there are some trade offs and the way that I like to represent this is that with this triangle where you have cost performance and resiliency Unfortunately you cannot have them all so you can go actually check this blog post that I wrote recently where I go in more detail about it but you can get the performance that you expected to have notice that it might increase the and you can actually be reducing the cost but notice that the resiliency might affect it So it's about a balance it's about a trade off and the idea of what I'm going to start sharing from this onwards is a few practical tips that if you're not today autoscaling effectively or you're thinking about KEDA or Carpenter in some future I hope that these practical tips are going to be useful for you So let's cover about the typical scenario that we have with KEDA and Carpenter Typically you will see that traffic is stable on the node and you will start creating a KEDA autoscaling rule that is going to start scaling on the throughput or the request per seconds This is very traditional and when the request per second increased you basically are going to add in more pods KEDA is basically an abstraction layer on HPA so even if you are still scaling on CPU utilization I will highly recommend you to get started with KEDA because you can still scale based on CPU but you will start getting all these benefits that I'm going to cover So at some point the capacity on the cluster is going to be constrained you have unscheduled pods and then that's where Carpenter comes in and it's going create the nodes that you need All right so that's very simple At some point you can see here that in terms of efficiency it's going to just create the node that it needs and nothing more nothing less depending on your constraints as well We can again we can talk about and cover a lot of things on how to make it more efficient and again how to balance between reliability and cost But the reality all of that sounds good and maybe you've seen all of those scenarios in very traditional or very introductory sessions about KEDA and Carpenter but the reality is this Too many things are going to be happening when that event comes in and there are too many variables that come into play So you have a lot of delays you have a lot of synchronization that is going to happen at the same time So how can you think about it You're going to have the delay of getting the metrics you're going to have the delay of bootstrapping the node When you get the node up and running you have to wait for the node to register and if you're working right now and deploying AI models or AI based workloads you have to wait for that image to be downloaded and so on Things can get complicated and messy if you don't consider all of these constraints and variants So we can do better and hopefully I'm going to start throwing a few tips and recommendations of what I've seen and what I have not seen on many sessions when people start talking about KEDA and Carpenter So what I'm surprised that not many people talk about KEDA is of course the typical example that you have with request per second and SQS or queue based scaling and you have basically you can scale down to zero However you can speed up the scaling decisions and with this configuration what I'm doing is because remember what I said before KEDA works on top of HPA and what I'm doing here is basically reacting as fast as I can on adding more and as conservative as I can on removing replicas because you might have spikes on traffic and you don't want to be too aggressive on removing the replicas when scaling down The other interesting thing with KEDA is that in case you didn't know you can actually configure multiple triggers So you can say like as I was saying before maybe it's not about only one metric for scaling maybe it's about CPU utilization as well and memory utilization request per second latency or queue depth or whichever metric you think is useful for you So the first scaler that takes into action is going to run it's going to add the replicas that it needs so basically you're covered from different upfronts However with KEDA you can also have the ability of doing more complicated things You can combine these scalers and what is interesting here is that of course you can configure here and get the metrics from for example for Prometheus and the typical case that I'm showing here is that you might be too aggressive on scaling out but if that happens if you don't take care of that you might be actually causing problems to the database for example So there might be occasions where you actually at some point you might want to say hey hold on I know that I have a problem and I need to scale out but if I continue doing so I'm going to create more problems that I have today So you can actually use the scale modifiers and you can actually have formulas here that you can say if the database write latency is lower than 100 milliseconds stop don't scale or continue scaling or keep it static Right now when the database is relaxed I can continue scaling So that's basically the benefits of using KEDA What about Carpenter Carpenter we already know is going to write size and the request that you send into the pod is extremely important because that is going to drive which compute capacity Carpenter is going to launch Too many people that are new to Carpenter think that it's basically about utilization when it's not It's basically about request and basically the resources that Kubernetes is going to have to guarantee that you have on the nodes It's basically allocated resources not utilization Why is it important Because Carpenter is going to try to make decisions on choosing the lowest price instance possible If it's going to be on the case of AWS it's going to use the lowest price If it's going to be spot again it's going to prioritize capacity but it's going to launch the cheapest available The other things that we can do here with Carpenter and maybe you are not aware of it based on some recent features that we released is that you can basically influence the schedule algorithm the Kubernetes the Carpenter algorithm and bid packing simulation that it does and influence the instance type that you're going to get And of course there are a few things that you can implement as well on bootstrapping the instance more quickly So the first thing is that we released a few weeks ago node overlays and this is basically an override that you can have on the certain requirements that you have in So in this case you could say based on the test that I did at the beginning I noticed that Graviton outperformed x86 and of course I want to have flexibility on using multi architectures but I want to give preference on a more recent generation of capacity So in this case it could be Graviton or you could actually prefer to have the latest generation before considering any other instance type Because again as I was saying before otherwise Carpenter is going to go with the lowest price available and this is a way that you can influence that as well So you can say like hey the price adjustment is going to be actually cheaper on this latest generation Even in reality it might be more costly but the price performance is going to be better for you Then node overlays it started as a price override but it's also now in the AI era You can actually influence and tell Carpenter that that GPU node in reality instead of using one GPU you can time slice it and with the help of other schedulers on that context now it's going to use that and put that in practice But this is a way of you can influence that On the Carpenter side as well it's a pretty easy trick if you are going to be doing this for performance bootstrap You can actually configure a rate zero on your disk Different instance types in AWS have multiple NVMe disks and if you want to make use of all of them effectively you might have to use user data and configure all of that Don't worry about that You just have to use instance store policy rate zero and with this container D and when you're pulling images are going to be using this disk and it's going to be faster How can we increase that with such a parallel pull request as well In a node class you can actually configure this user data We have a blog we have a few blueprints that you can take a and the such a parallel pull request it's basically a feature that it's going to try to parallelize all the downloads of different layers at the same time of the container image So we can see here that sometimes we've seen customers reducing 50  of the time of the pull when pulling large images Maybe last but not least if you're using Bottlerocket you can make use of data volumes and what is interesting here is that you can use a snapshot ID where you can pre cache either container layers or a big model that you have or even model weights if that's your use case and do something like this Effectively what it does is that we release a project where you can take a snapshot of the container images that you create you can use that snapshot and you can basically inject that snapshot at bootstrap time and you can reduce the time very efficiently on this I want to show you here I know I don't have much time left but what I did here is basically I actually put in practice this This is the just basically pass the docker image that I want the disk size that I want and it's going to take a while like 10 minutes on creating this It's going to produce a snapshot ID here So before that the container image was taking almost four minutes eight minutes to get ready and pulling down After that it only actually took 44 seconds to pull down the image because the image was already there So even though if your image is not that big or you're not planning on two maybe this is an efficient trick that you can use on this I'm not sure if I wasn't you were not seeing that right This one Sorry about that So this was basically I thought I was showing you this but this is basically you can see the events that were the previous spot that was not efficient was taking too much time and this was basically 40 taking 44 seconds right Of course the idea was to show this live but I'm running out of time now So just to close off what I want to have a takeaway here is that scaling based on CPU memory is limited Hopefully you can consider other types of scaling mechanisms Instrument your applications from day one It's pretty important and I'm pretty sure that you might already have been using Prometheus Take advantage of that of those metrics Continuous profiling with Aperf Keren Carpenter is going to help you to make this efficient auto scaling but you have to do the job of rightsizing making sure that you are choosing the right instance for your workload And as I was saying before compute is only one angle Think about storage networking and this is going to become even more and more relevant as we evolve into the industry with AIML workloads Yeah 30 minutes was somewhat enough to give you an overview about this So thanks for having me today I'm going to be around if you have any questions Thank you
